description: From Middle English vaunten, from Anglo-Norman vaunter, variant of Old French vanter, from Latin vānus (“vain, boastful”).

entries.meaning: A boast; an instance of vaunting.
examples: He has answered me back, vaunt for vaunt, rhetoric for rhetoric.

verbs.description: vaunt (third-person singular simple present vaunts, present participle vaunting, simple past and past participle vaunted)

examples: "The number," said he, "is great, but what can be expected from mere citizen soldiers? They vaunt and menace in time of safety; none are so arrogant when the enemy is at a distance; but when the din of war thunders at the gates they hide themselves in terror."

entries.meaning: (transitive) To boast of; to make a vain display of; to display with ostentation.

description: French avant (“before, fore”). See avant, vanguard.
